repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.abstract: Collection contains correspondence, publications, newspaper clippings, speeches, legal documents, photographs, audiotapes, and videotapes. The material dates from ca. 1950-2002, although the bulk is from 1977-2002. They are the papers of Jacob Dan Nimrod, largely from the time he resumed his writing career in 1977 until his death in 2002. The material in the collection covers the wide range of Nimrod's political writing activities, mainly concerning Israeli politics and foreign relations. Other prominent topics include apartheid in South Africa and the civil war in Nicaragua. It also includes the writings he saved of some of his correspondents.

prefercite.head: Preferred citation
prefercite.p: Dan Nimrod papers, Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: In 2000, Nimrod donated his library of over 2,500 volumes and his extensive archives to The George Washington University.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Jacob Dan Nimrod (1923-2002) was a Polish-Israeli-Canadian political commentator, active in various Zionist causes.

Born in what is today the Ukraine (then part of Poland) in 1923, Dan Nimrod, originally named Ya'acov Hebel, was active in the Zionist movement from a young age. At age 15, he migrated across Europe on foot to reach what was then British Mandatory Palestine.

At the outbreak of World War II, Nimrod enlisted in the British Army's Jewish Palestinian Unit and served in North Africa. He successfully defended himself against desertion charges, which arose when he joined the Irgun Zvai Leumi (National Military Organization). In 1944, Irgun began fighting British authorities for the creation of a Jewish state in Palestine. At war's end, Nimrod served as Irgun's commander in several European countries, joining its general staff in 1947. He also directed the organization's public information service in Eastern Europe and worked to acquire weapons in France.

On May 14, 1948, Israel officially declared its independence. Almost immediately, several surrounding Arab countries attacked. Nimrod fought in the subsequent war (1948-49) while continuing his work to supply the Jewish State with weapons from Europe. After the war ended, Nimrod served on the central committee for the Israeli nationalist party Herut (which later formed part of the Likud Party) and was an unsuccessful candidate for the Knesset (the Israeli parliament). In 1949, Nimrod married his first wife, Esther Grachanek, who later passed away from natural causes. During the early 1950s, Nimrod remained active in Israeli politics, regularly penning columns under the name Ya'acov Lotan.

In 1956, Nimrod emigrated to Canada. He initially settled in Newfoundland, but later moved to Montreal. He initially served as a principal at a Jewish school but later became an independent teacher of Hebrew. Nimrod married Anita Affholter, originally from Switzerland, in 1961.

Nimrod resumed his writing career anew in 1977, after his old friend, Menachem Begin, was elected prime minister of Israel. He founded the Canadian Jewish Herald, a compendium of articles relating to Israeli politics, to counter what he saw as attacks on Begin and the Likud Party in other media.

Nimrod formed the self-financed Dawn Publishing Company as part of that effort in 1979. Over the next 23 years, he edited, authored, or compiled 62 books, newspapers, monographs, magazines, anthologies, position papers, and special dossiers, and corresponded with people around the world as part of his campaigns.

In 2000, Nimrod donated his library of over 2,500 volumes and his extensive archives to The George Washington University. He desired to present a "different perspective" on the Arab-Israeli conflict to researchers in the capital of the United States.
Nimrod died in Montreal on April 22, 2002.

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection contains correspondence, publications, newspaper clippings, speeches, legal documents, photographs, audiotapes, and videotapes. The material dates from ca. 1950-2002, although the bulk is from 1977-2002. They are the papers of Jacob Dan Nimrod, largely from the time he resumed his writing career in 1977 until his death in 2002. The material in the collection covers the wide range of Nimrod's political writing activities, mainly concerning Israeli politics and foreign relations. Other prominent topics include apartheid in South Africa and the civil war in Nicaragua. It also includes the writings he saved of some of his correspondents.

Nimrod's estate donated the material to The George Washington University following Nimrod's death in 2002. The correspondence is arranged by the country of the correspondent. Within each correspondence series, it is arranged in alphabetical order by individual correspondent or organization, except for general folders such as "Special Interest" and "Organizations." Within each folder, the correspondence is sorted chronologically. Nimrod's estate also included cross-references in many of the folders.

The collection also contains the papers of Sol Modell, a frequent correspondent of Nimrod's and a former professor of history at Los Angeles Valley College. Upon Modell's death, his family donated the papers to Florida Atlantic University in Boca Raton, Florida, where Modell had retired. The university transferred them to Nimrod, who included them with his papers donated to The George Washington University.

arrangement.head: Collection Organization
arrangement.p: Organized into 12 series: Correspondence - Israel; Correspondence - Canada; Correspondence - Germany; Correspondence - United Kingdom; Correspondence - United States; Correspondence - Other Countries; Biographical Information - Prominent Correspondents; Publications, Book Reviews and Promotional Materials; Biographical Information - Nimrod; Sol Modell, papers; Ephemera.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains Nimrod's correspondence with people and organizations in Israel, mostly activists. It includes letters between him and prominent government officials, including former Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. The bulk of the material dates from 1977-2002. Some of the material in this series is in Hebrew. This series is organized by correspondent's last name or organization name, then chronologically within each folder. Folders labeled "Special Interest" and "Organizations" contain multiple correspondents, sorted alphabetically within those folders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains Nimrod's correspondence with people and organizations in Canada. The bulk of the material dates from 1977-2002. Some of the material is in French. It includes Dan and Anita Nimrod's papers from their campaign to gain official recognition for Israel's Magen David Adom from the International Committee of the Red Cross. Most of the other material is Nimrod's correspondence. It also contains Nimrod's letters to the editor, open letters, "Dear Friends" letters, and "Dear Reader" letters. This series is organized by correspondent's last name or organization name, then chronologically within each folder. Folders labeled "Special Interest," "Media-General," "Media-Jewish," and "Organizations" contain multiple correspondents.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains Nimrod's correspondence with people and organizations in Germany. The material dates from 1979-2002. The majority of the writings are Nimrod's correspondence with Erich Sontag, a commentator with similar views to those of Nimrod. These folders also contain Sontag's writings that he sent to Nimrod. This series is organized by correspondent's last name or organization name, then chronologically within each folder. The folder labeled "Special Interest" contains multiple correspondents, sorted alphabetically within that folder.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: [from contents page of folder:] Embassy of Israel; International Books in Print; Juristenzeitung; Meyer, Hartmut; Osteuropa; Rohler, Andreas; Springer, Axel; Ticauer, Sholomo (prof); Troy State University Europe

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains Nimrod's correspondence with people and organizations in the United Kingdom. The material dates from 1977-2002. Sidney Goodman, a Zionist activist, is the most prominent correspondent in this series. These folders also contain Goodman's writings that he sent to Nimrod. This series is organized by correspondent's last name or organization name, then chronologically within each folder. Folders labeled "Special Interest," "Media-Jewish," "Archives - Libraries - Research Institutes - Misc.," and "Organizations" contain multiple correspondents, sorted alphabetically within those folders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains Nimrod's correspondence with people and organizations in the United States. The material dates from 1956-2002. Some more prominent correspondents include Monroe Spen, a Sarasota, Florida, real estate developer who founded Friends of the Jerusalem Temple Mount Inc., and Leonard Horwin, a former U.S. diplomat and mayor of Beverly Hills, California. Horwin self-published a newsletter called Plain Talk, copies of which Nimrod collected and included in his files of correspondence with Horwin. This series is organized by correspondent's last name or organization name, then chronologically within each folder. Folders labeled "Special Interest," "Media-Jewish," "Archives - Libraries - Misc.," and "Organizations" contain multiple correspondents, sorted alphabetically within those folders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains Nimrod's correspondence with people and organizations in other countries besides those in Series 1-5. The material dates from 1974-2002. Some of the material is in French. It includes correspondence with individuals and organizations in Australia, Belgium, Czechoslovakia (now the Czech Republic and Slovakia), France, Ghana, Greece, Holland (the Netherlands), Hong Kong, India, Ireland, Italy, various countries of Latin America, Malta, Mexico, Moldova Republic, New Zealand, Nigeria, the Philippines, South Africa, Spain, Switzerland, Turkey, and Zambia. The South Africa section contains copies of the Aida Parker Newsletter, from a prominent conservative activist and correspondent of Nimrod. This series is sorted by country, and within each country in alphabetical order by correspondent, then chronologically within each folder. Folders labeled "Special Interest," "Archives & Libraries," and "Archives - Libraries - Research Institutes" contain multiple correspondents, sorted alphabetically within those folders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains short biographical sketches of some of Nimrod's more prominent correspondents, and also of Israeli cabinet officials in the 1980s. Some are photocopies of autobiographies, others are official biographies of individuals, and some are biographies written by Nimrod to accompany his mailings of these individuals' writings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains publications by Dan Nimrod and Dawn Publishing Company. It contains books, bound copies, and stapled circular correspondence. It includes some of Nimrod's early educational manuals. The material dates from 1959-2002, but the bulk is from 1977-2002. It is sorted in chronological order. Most of the material relates to the Arab-Israeli conflict, but includes other issues such as apartheid in South Africa and the Nicaraguan civil war.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The original box 16 was too heavy and prone to damage. The files in the original box 16 were divided into boxes 16A-16D, but the folder numbers remained the same. So for this set of boxes each box does not begin with a folder 1.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains book reviews by Nimrod and by others about Dawn Publishing's works. It also contains material, mostly letters, related to Nimrod's activities promoting his publications. The material dates from 1977-2002.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The original box 16 was too heavy and prone to damage. The files in the original box 16 were divided into boxes 16A-16D, but the folder numbers remained the same. So for this set of boxes each box does not begin with a folder 1.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains biographical information on Dan Nimrod. It includes copies of Nimrod's credentials for various organizations to which he belonged, biographies of him in various publications, and his newspaper columns from when he wrote in Israel in the early 1950s. The material dates from ca. 1938-2000. The Israeli period columns are in Hebrew with English translations of the titles.

did.unittitle: Dan Nimrod - Literary Activity: the Israeli period
Dan Nimrod - The One Man Zionist Hasbara Campaign
Eine Stimme fur Gerechtigkeit - in German
George Washington University - Address by Dan Nimrod at Dedication Ceremony
George Washington University - Reception in Honor of Dan Nimrod
Identity Cards and Certificates Related to Political Activities

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains the papers of Professor Sol Modell (1915-98), a correspondent of Dan Nimrod's whose papers went to Florida Atlantic University and subsequently to GWU as part of Nimrod's donation. The bulk of the material dates from 1968-95. It includes letters and newspaper clippings from Modell, largely related to Israeli politics and foreign relations, but sometimes to other issues as well. Modell, a professor at Los Angeles Valley College, was a columnist for Heritage, a Jewish newspaper in Los Angeles, and wrote to many individuals, mostly in the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains miscellaneous videos and audiotapes donated by Nimrod. It also contains a plaque from George Washington University to mark Nimrod's donation of his library in 2000. It includes an oral history with Yedidiah Blumenthal, a longtime Zionist activist in South Africa, and other documentaries selected by Nimrod to be included with his archives. Most of these documentaries pertain to the Arab-Israeli conflict and other Jewish issues.
